tutorial.title: Flexbox Axes
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn the difference between the main axis and the cross axis in Flexbox

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
The web is made out of all kinds of different websites from around the world that are in different languages.

Flexbox is a newer CSS feature designed to work the same for a global community of developers and web users.

lessons.title: Any direction
lessons.interactiveContent:
Websites can display content left to right, up to down, or in many other ways.

Flexbox is designed to be adaptable for any of these use cases.

lessons.title: No left and right
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using flexbox, we try to describe layouts according to where flex items start and end based on flex direction.

Make sure to pick row, followed by -, and finally reverse.

lessons.title: Main Axis
lessons.interactiveContent: The flex-direction defines what's known as the main axis, an imaginary line that refers to the direction and orientation of flex items.

lessons.title: Left to right
lessons.interactiveContent:
On the websites we're working on, flex-direction: row means the main axis is horizontal, starts from the left, and ends to the right.

Make sure to type row.

lessons.title: Right to left
lessons.interactiveContent:
flex-direction: row-reverse means the main axis is horizontal, but now starts from the right and ends on the left side.

Make sure to pick row-reverse.

lessons.title: Vertical
lessons.interactiveContent: To define the vertical axis as the main axis, we can set flex-direction to column or column-reverse.

lessons.title: Vertical main axis
lessons.interactiveContent:
flex-direction: column means the main axis is vertical, starts from the top, and ends at the bottom.

Make sure to type column.

lessons.title: Question: Any direction
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is true about flexbox?

Flexbox describes where items "start" and "end" in relation to the main axisFlexbox describes the direction of items with "left" and "right"

Flexbox describes where items "start" and "end" in relation to the main axis.

lessons.title: Question: No left and right
lessons.interactiveContent:
What main axis does this code have?

A vertical oneA horizontal one

A vertical one.

lessons.title: Question: Main Axis
lessons.interactiveContent:
What main axis does this code have?

A horizontal one, from left to rightA vertical one, from top to bottom

A horizontal one, from left to right.

lessons.title: Question: Left to right
lessons.interactiveContent:
What defines the main axis?

The flex directionThe container size

The flex direction.

lessons.title: Question: Right to left
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when we change flex-direction from row to row-reverse?

The start and end of the main axis changes, but the orientation doesn'tThe main axis changes its orientation

The start and end of the main axis changes, but the orientation doesn't.

lessons.title: Question: No left and right
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does flex-direction do when it's set to column-reverse?

It makes the main axis be vertical, start from the bottom and end at the topIt makes the main axis be horizontal, start from the left and end to right

It makes the main axis be vertical, start from the bottom and end at the top.

lessons.title: Example: Any direction
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make the main axis be vertical for this container.

Make sure to pick flex-direction followed by : and then column, ;.

lessons.title: Example: No left and right
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make flex items start from the bottom of the container.

Make sure to pick column, followed by -, and finally reverse.

lessons.title: Example: Main Axis
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make the main axis display horizontally and start from the left of the container.

Make sure to pick row.

lessons.title: Example: Right to left
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make the main axis display horizontally and start from the right side of the container by coding row-reverse.

Make sure to pick row, followed by -, and finally reverse.

lessons.title: Example: Vertical
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make the main axis be vertical and start from the top.

Make sure to pick column.

lessons.title: Example: No left and right
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make this navigation menu work for languages that start from the right side of the webpage.

Make sure to pick row, followed by -, and finally reverse.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
So far we've established that the main axis is based on flex-direction. Make the flex items display on a horizontal main-axis.

Make sure to pick row-reverse.

lessons.title: Cross axis
lessons.interactiveContent:
Flexbox containers also have a cross axis, which is an imaginary line perpendicular to the main axis.

The flex-direction property denotes the main axis. So with flex-direction: row , the main axis will be horizontal and the cross axis vertical.

lessons.title: Row
lessons.interactiveContent:
By using row or row-reverse as the flex-direction property, we can make the cross axis vertical. Let's try it out!

Make sure to pick row.

lessons.title: Start and end
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we add a height to the items and container, we can see the cross-axis for row and row-reverse starts at the top and ends at the bottom.

Make sure to pick row-reverse.

lessons.title: Column
lessons.interactiveContent: For column and column-reverse, the cross axis is always horizontal.

lessons.title: Start and end column
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we add width to the items, we can see the cross axis for column and column-reverse starts to the left and ends to the right.

Make sure to pick column-reverse.

lessons.title: Talking like a developer
lessons.interactiveContent:
Don't worry about remembering all the details about the main or cross axes! We'll get plenty of practice in the following chapters.

For now, it's good to keep them in mind since we'll use them to describe other Flexbox properties.

lessons.title: Question: Cross axis
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the cross axis?

An imaginary line perpendicular to the main axisAn imaginary line parallel to the main axis

An imaginary line perpendicular to the main axis.

lessons.title: Question: Cross row
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when flex-direction is set to row or row-reverse?

The cross axis is verticalThe cross axis is horizontal

The cross axis is vertical.

lessons.title: Question: Start and end
lessons.interactiveContent:
Where does the cross axis start when flex-direction is set to row?

It starts from the topIt starts from the bottom

It starts from the top.

lessons.title: Question: Column
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when flex-direction is set to column or  column-reverse?

The cross axis is horizontalThe cross axis is vertical

The cross axis is horizontal.

lessons.title: Question: Start and end column
lessons.interactiveContent:
Where does the cross axis start when flex-direction is set to column?

It starts from the leftIt starts from the right

It starts from the left.

lessons.title: Example: Row
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the right flex-direction to make the cross axis be vertical.

Make sure to pick row.

lessons.title: Example: Column
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the right flex-direction to make the main axis be vertical and the cross axis be horizontal.

Make sure to pick column.

lessons.title: Example: Row 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the flex-direction property to make the main axis horizontal and the cross axis vertical.

Make sure to pick row-reverse.

lessons.title: Example: Column 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the right flex-direction to make the cross axis be horizontal.

Make sure to pick column-reverse.
